title: In its 2020 referendum, will Puerto Rico vote to become a state?
preds: This was a dumb question for me to have answered. So few data points. Crowd is at 95%. I normally extremize but I'm going the other way because I don't believe anyone knows anything about this one.
they voted for statehood in 2017 by an overwhelming 95% (only 22% of the people voted).
Historically, only approximately 1/3 have voted for statehood.  They receive federal aid but are not required to pay federal taxes.
I haven't seen any polling that is actually decent or has 'Yes' with a clear enough lead to give anywhere near the certainty of the crowd here.

-  Because the polling for this referendum is virtually nonexistent, I am shifting to a different view.
 - Using the summer governer primaries the following was identified. 
- 281,000 voters for the PNP (pro-statehood) turned out
- 204,000 voters for the PPD (pro-independence) 
- Polls continue to swing between the candidates within the statistical margin of error (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/governor/puerto-rico/)
- SO all of this to say, the vote is going to be a toss up.  Do the PPD vote show up this year, unlike the last election? How does a Y/N vote impact the polling when previous votes were Y/N/Status quo

Based on information in the comments, I'm revising from 100% to 85% because my initial perspective was more from the article information and historical user of referendums politically and only having in person opinions available initially from those that have moved to the US or served with me in the military after graduating from military schools there. That set of people probably won't be voting in the referendum.

If you had it the day after the US elections, I think Biden winning will make the process seem less urgent. But the threat of Trump winning the election will influence Puerto Rico to vote for the fastest option, which would be statehood, to assure additional rights in times that seem uncertain, with widespread economic instability. Statehood will seem like the most stable and secure option on Nov 3 election day in particular.

Change (-17) While it is logical that Puerto Rico will vote for statehood as they have in previous elections and a desire for more federal funds following Hurricane Maria there is still a lot of uncertainty. There hasn't been a lot of polling, you can see all of it on Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Puerto_Rican_status_referendum), but the latest poll has this question at a statistical tie (https://radioisla.tv/jennifer-gonzalez-domina-la-contienda-a-la-comisaria-residente/) with a lot of voters undecided.  The biggest complication is that compared to previous statehood elections the anti-statehood party (the PDP) is not boycotting the referendum. Their boycotts are what led the margin to be so lopsided in favor of statehood in 2012 and 2017. Indeed, this time the referendum will be held the same day as local elections in Puerto Rico and with the question being a straight Yes/No as opposed to the 3 part questions on previous ballots there is no way for the anti-statehood block (which considers a myriad of options) to be divided. Additionally, while the PNP have a plurality of support the rest of the support is divided amongst the PDP and opposition parties a few of whom have different plans for statehood. Furthermore 6% of PNP voters think the question is pointless because it has not been congressionally approved and sentiment on the island is that this referendum is a political stunt for the PNP to drive its voters to the polls. Frankly, I don't think mainlanders understand politics in Puerto Rico at all as evidence by the crowd giving this a 95% chance of passing. Views in Puerto Rico actually appear quite jaded on the statehood question, there was even a dust-up amongst legislators of Puerto Rican descent and politicians on the island about the best way forward (https://www.nbcnews.com/news/latino/new-aoc-vel-zquez-bill-puerto-rico-s-status-sparks-n1238192). In my estimation what is driving people to be confident in this question is they see statehood as something Puerto Ricans want following the Hurricane, they think Puerto Ricans vote like democrats and hate Donald Trump, and they think Puerto Rico is desperate to shed their status (while the latter is true there is a lot of debate over how to do it and also this referendum many believe will not change their status).  TLDR: While the existing evidence (polling and sentiment following the hurricane) supports an affirmative outcome there remains a lot of uncertainty as this will be the first referendum in which the PDP is not boycotting and views of statehood on the island are complicated by perceptions that this being on the ballot is a political stunt. Additionally, polling shows a toss-up vote with a lot of undecided voters.

The latest poll conducted in PR showed a 75% favor of statehood.  This is down from the 2017 vote at 96% in favor of statehood.  There is a perception that the Dems will win the US presidential election and they are in favor of PR statehood.  This provides a better path towards statehood for PR that wasn't as clear as before.

Given that there has been no minimum % of the vote required for this to be the result, it is unlikely to change significantly since 2017. For those wondering why I am keeping with my low estimate, I have been generally aware of PR statehood issue since the 90's. I do think the economic benefits of remaining a territory are sound. Folks will always act in their own self-interests and being a territory has financial gains. I also recognize the desire among others who could seek two more Senate seats given the looming Dem sweep. But it comes down to a matter of plurality support for statehood with a majority of voters actually participating in an election. Prior referendums were poorly attended and while support numbers were high, there was not a mandate for statehood. That said, I am also using this question as a test whether my assessment is biased toward past sentiments. Thereupon I would acknowledge I should have jacked my estimate higher.  There is also a tendency for D administrations to be more sympathetic to PR issues, solidifying the notion that remaining a territory would restore advantages one could perceive as lost under a R administration - like Hurricane response...

The change to the simple Yes or No for the referendum should only help. The 2017 referendum passed easily, although with extremely low turnout. Even with a Presidential election and governor election at the top of the ticket, polling still shows a clear majority support for statehood in the simple Yes or No format.

As I read the polling data, it's a bit hard to follow because they asked separately whether respondents would answer the status question from whether they would vote in general. 75% said they were certain to vote and 82% said >8/10 on likelihood to vote overall, but only 57% said they would answer the status question. This creates a problem for interpreting the data because those saying they will vote on status question are much more in favor of statehood  (70%) than those that say they won't or are not sure (31%),  Unless someone can point otherwise, it seems like the question will be on the same ballot, so I presume a much higher share of actual voters will vote for the question, and so I expect a midpoint vote share of ~60% in favor, implying a lower probability than the current crowd forecast.  The last polling (Sept 14-18) has this at 53%, which is very similar to prior polling at 54% (July 2020). This is fairly consistent with prior year polling with three options (statehood, status quo, independence) where statehood got 48-57%.

Key drivers for voting for statehood are a lapsing economy, lack of rights that other US citizens have, and more sway in politics that would benefit PR.  However, 2018 was PR's 6th time voting for statehood and every time a vote of Yes went forward to Congress, it was ignored. Also, the US has no formal process towards statehood. All these factors make PRs cynical of any Yes vote equating to support in Congress.  The combination of a pro-statehood gov't in place in PR, the last three votes in 2016-18 were a yes, and the perception by PR that Democrats will lead America soon, I see a high probability of another yes.

Gov. Wanda Vasquez announced the decision to hold a referendum on Puerto Rico in May.  This decision was based on Puerto Rican recovery efforts on recent hurricanes (Maria and Irma, in particular) and recent coronavirus concerns.   Referendums in Puerto Rico on statehood in 2012 and 2017 resulted in majorities for statehood, and this was before the most recent hurricanes and coronavirus.  The results of this referendum are also dependent on whether the PPD participate or boycott (as they did in 2017).  However, it is likely that support for statehood has grown due to natural disasters in which access to federal aid would be more forthcoming. Outside:  there is bipartisan legislation moving through congress (as of 15 Sept) to support the results of the referendum (though the republicans that support this legislation are from US territories).  The last two territories admitted to the Union were in 1959, but there is a not insignificant uptick in conversation about DC being recognized as a state.  Puerto Rico, who has struggled with federal assistance in the wake of multiple hurricanes, may see statehood as a way to remedy internal economic pressures and increase federal agency.   https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/puerto-rico-hold-statehood-referendum-amid-disillusion-70723188,,, It appears this question on the referendum will be worded differently.  Previous iterations offered: commonwealth, statehood, status quo, or independence.  Votes prior to 2017 had splits between commonwealth, statehood, and status quo... but 2017 (a relatively contested election) had 97% for statehood.  Assuming similar voter turnout compared to 2017, and the revision of the question on the referendum to a binary choice, I give a slightly positive assessment for the referendum.

There have been 5 previous such votes. The last one in June 2017 passed by 97% in part because the opposition parties boycotted the vote and in part because it was a non election year vote. It only had 21% turnout. The 2016 election had a 55% turnout in Puerto Rico. I expect this election to have somewhere between the 21% and 55% turnout. There is a growing feeling in Puerto Rico that voting doesn't matter because all decisions are made by Congress or committee anyway. And so I would expect that those that do vote would be people who want Puerto Rico to become a state so that they can gain the right to vote. the 2017 referendum was considered a victory by those opposing statehood because they skewed the outcome so much that it is not considered a reliable vote. I haven't seen anything stating that the opposition parties have a similar strategy this time around, but even if they haven't publicized such a strategy there may be many members of the opposition parties that still abstain for that reason. Based on all of these factors I think that the polls of people's opinion are worthless. As a side note I think that statehood would be terrible for Puerto Rico. Puerto Rico is the only place in the world where you can have the protections of US citizenship and a US passport and yet not pay US income taxes. there has been a growing movement of wealthy Americans moving to Puerto Rico to avoid taxes and this has been bringing money into the territory. If Puerto Rico became a state, yes they would likely get more Medicare money but they would also have to deal with a huge tax increase and they would suddenly become responsible for their portion of the US national debt. $3bil in Medicaid money is not worth massive taxes and massive debt. And who cares if you can vote in the national election. Your vote as an individual isn't going to have any influence anyway.

Suspect low turnout and distractions within beltway will leave status quo for awhile...unless Democrats get in (Puerto Ricans more likely to vote Dem but currently can’t vote in presidential elections).
